meta.content: How education has changed in the San Gabriel Valley during coronavirus shutdown
Most school districts are forging ahead into uncharted territory: remote learning. That means a whole new world for teachers, their students and the studentsâ€™ parents.

h1.span: How education has changed in the San Gabriel Valley during coronavirus shutdown

a.title: Click to share on Facebook

figure.figcaption: Office assistant Stephanie Diaz hands a Chromebook to Angelina Valencia, 8, at Hurley Elementary School in La Puente so they can start their remote learning on Friday March 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Durflinger)

div.div: PUBLISHED: March 25, 2020 at 4:34 p.m. | UPDATED: March 25, 2020 at 4:36 p.m.

div.p: Itâ€™s been 1Â½ weeks since Californiaâ€™s K-12 public schools shifted from classroom instruction to distance learning to protect the public from the new coronavirus pandemic, and teachers, parents and students across the San Gabriel Valley have settled into homeschooling.

Those districts with existing digital initiatives and efficient planning are finding the transition easier than those without, and homeschooling the elementary student can be more challenging than their older siblings.

img.p: Office assistant Stephanie Diaz hands a Chromebook to Adrian Domingo, 9, with his father, Abrocio, center, and his sister, Jacqueline, back, at Hurley Elementary School in La Puente so they can start their remote learning on Friday March 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Durflinger)

Brian Huff, Director of Instructional Support, takes a photo of as the Rowland Unified School District is passes out Chromebooks to all students at Hurley Elementary School in La Puente so they can start their remote learning on Friday March 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Durflinger)

Dr. Rebecca Rodriguez hands a Chromebook to third grader, Matthew Mendoza, center, and his brother, Mark Estrada, right, at Hurley Elementary School in La Puente so they can start their remote learning on Friday March 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Durflinger)

The Rowland Unified School District is passing out Chromebooks to all students at Hurley Elementary School in La Puente so they can start their remote learning on Friday March 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Durflinger)

Dr. Rebecca Rodriguez hands a Chromebook to sixth grader, Samantha Lopez, 11, and her father, Juan, at Hurley Elementary School in La Puente so they can start their remote learning on Friday March 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Durflinger)

Office assistant Stephanie Diaz hands a Chromebook to Angelina Valencia, 8, at Hurley Elementary School in La Puente so they can start their remote learning on Friday March 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Durflinger)

a.span: Expand

div.p: Meanwhile, some districts, including San Marino and Arcadia unified, have decided to make remote learning optional.

In response to the new coronavirus pandemic, the Los Angeles County Office of Education requested on March 13 that all schools close for at least two weeks starting Monday, March 16. The recommendation has since been extended to May 5, although individual school districts will have the final say.

In many districts, the sudden notice left too little time for schools to cobble together a structured remote study program. But the leadership team at Pasadena Unified acted early. Before the countyâ€™s announcement, officials canceled public events and initiated a backup plan for reinforcement learning, said Helen Chan Hill, the districtâ€™s director of curriculum, instruction and professional development.
The school board granted Superintendent Brian McDonald emergency powers days before other districts, so he could respond immediately to the changing environment.
When the schools closed, teachers were prepared to assign two weeksâ€™ worth of general content to every student.

â€œWeâ€™ve been watching the coronavirus spread for some time and took note of how other countries are preparing,â€ Hill said. â€œWe wanted to guarantee kids didnâ€™t leave school feeling like they have nothing to do.â€

PUSD also got a head start because students were already familiar with digital tools, Hill said. Two years ago, the district implemented the 1:1 Tech Equity Take Home Program, which furnished each middle and high schooler a Chromebook to use in class and at home.

It also provided PUSD funding to hire instructional coaches and tech leaders, who guided teachers through apps such as Zoom and Google Classroom â€” the very tools other districts are rushing out to teachers.
â€œThe main objective is that students have a stable environment,â€ Hill said. â€œWe want to make distance learning as easy and as familiar as possible.â€

Like Pasadena, Rowland Unified is another district thatâ€™s ahead of the pack in blending technology with classroom instruction. In November 2018, Rowland â€” along with five other San Gabriel Valley school districts â€” partnered up with the 1 Million Project Foundation to provide high-speed internet access to high schoolers. That same year, the district also began loaning tablets to students from seventh to 12th grades
When the closures were announced, the district put aside roughly 3,000 Chromebooks, mostly for K-6 students, Superintendent Julie Mitchell said. As of last Friday, it had distributed 2,606 tablets.
â€œWe are a future-ready district,â€ she said. â€œWhile learning outside of school is new, the work behind it is not.â€

Rather than hitting parents and students all at once with the new demands, school districts are rolling out the plan in three phases. The first stage, which lasts two weeks, focuses on enrichment, ensuring that students and parents receive the technological and emotional support they need through the transition.
In Phase 2, which for many starts after the spring break, teachers will incorporate more technology and electives will be added.
The final stage will be full-fledged live instruction with a structured schedule â€” the details of which many schools are still finalizing.

At the moment, the process is not entirely streamlined. Not all schools, for example, use the same digital platforms. Many have yet to deploy conferencing apps. As a result, some students have had to communicate with teachers solely by email, which isnâ€™t nearly as effective as in-person instruction.

Stefin Bank, a sixth grader at Clifton Middle School in Monrovia, said heâ€™d often have to ask his mother for help with math problems. Although his teacher would email back â€œwithin three minutes,â€ he said, he finds it much easier to phrase questions aloud.
â€œItâ€™s been pretty hard because my mom isnâ€™t as good as my teachers,â€ he said, half-joking.
His mother, Julie Bank, has found herself taking the role of tutor and student.

â€œI havenâ€™t been in school for a long time,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™ve had to use Alexa to help him with assignments.â€ She said sheâ€™s personally contacted the principal about integrating Zoom in remote learning and was told that the move is being considered but not finalized.
Despite the complications, she said sheâ€™s been impressed by how quickly teachers have grasped the new technology: â€œEveryday, itâ€™s better.â€
Some districts have not made off-site learning mandatory. Arcadia and San Marino unifieds have made remote learning optional out of concern that not every student has access to digital tools

â€œSimply put, as a state, we are not yet able to deliver on an equitable education to all, both from a technical standpoint and legal framework, San Marino Superintendent Jeff Wilson said in a letter posted on the districtâ€™s website. His comments reference possible litigation.

â€œWhile SMUSD families and schools are well-equipped to participate in a virtual environment, there are many areas of the state where this is not true.Â While private schools need not concern themselves with equal access and FAPE (free and appropriate public education) laws, we are held to a different legal standard,â€ he wrote.

A March 15 message from Arcadia Unified reports students â€œwill not be graded, penalized, or held accountable for instruction or learning materials provided during this time of school closures, all offerings are optional. We want to respect our teachers and staff who also have families.â€

Despite that, the district has made numerous resources available. In a video posted March 17, â€œThere is no one-size-fits-all solution when students go home. We have to follow guidelines and legal advice coming down from the county and state. Itâ€™s not the time for districts to act on its own.â€
He added the district is now in the pivot phase to a structured remote learning program.

For younger students, especially those from kindergarten to fifth grade, the shift to home learning requires a bit more hand-holding. Few experienced technical difficulties with such apps as Seesaw and Nearpod, but some found the change in scenery jarring.
Miriam Zavala, who has two sons at Hurley Elementary School in La Puente, said the younger one, a kindergartner, has trouble staying on task at home.
â€œHeâ€™d tell me Iâ€™m not his teacher,â€ she said of Joseph. â€œItâ€™s frustrating because there are lessons that I need to teach him, that we need to work on together.â€
Zavala said sheâ€™s been pleased by how organized and communicative teachers have been, but wishes they can provide a bit more support to parents going forward.
â€œThey could explain to the kids that, right now, itâ€™s your mom whoâ€™s going to be the teacher,â€ she said.

Heidi West, Josephâ€™s teacher at Hurley, recommended parents establish a set schedule with their children. In individual Zoom meetings with families, West has also suggested carving out time for entertainment and exercise, so kids can release excess energy.

li.a: LA Countyâ€™s coronavirus-spurred school closures could be extended into May

div.p: John, one of her kindergartners, has taken the advice very seriously. â€œHe tells me everyday, â€˜Remember that Ms. West said we can watch TV,â€™â€ his mother, Jazmin Mendoza, said.
Heâ€™s still getting used to the new learning environment, she added, and would sometimes throw tantrums. But sticking to a set routine has been helpful.
â€œItâ€™s been really good helping him out,â€ Mendoza continued. â€œWhen heâ€™s older, heâ€™s going to remember this time we spent together.â€

div.div: Claire Wang is a reporter based in Orange County, covering culture, politics, and Asian-American issues. Before that, she lived in New York for six years, during which she served an ill-advised stint as a music writer and graduated from Columbia Journalism School. Her bylines have appeared in The American Prospect, South China Morning Post, Vice, and others. She spends too much time listening to garage rock and watching A24 movies.

Although we do not pre-screen comments, we reserve the right at all times to remove any information or materials that are unlawful, threatening, abusive, libelous, defamatory, obscene, vulgar, pornographic, profane, indecent or otherwise objectionable to us, and to disclose any information necessary to satisfy the law, regulation, or government request. We might permanently block any user who abuses these conditions.

If you see comments that you find offensive, please use the â€œFlag as Inappropriateâ€ feature by hovering over the right side of the post, and pulling down on the arrow that appears. Or, contact our editors by emailing moderator@scng.com.
